channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Surgical wonders and dodgy medical ethics: the Hunterian Museum reopens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01736-0

The London museum is a treasure chest of medical specimens both fascinating and ghoulish — now with a renewed focus on questions about how its collections came to be.
item.dc:title: Surgical wonders and dodgy medical ethics: the Hunterian Museum reopens
item.dc:creator: Nisha Gaind

item.title: ‘Almost magical’: chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01735-1

An explosion of skeletal editing methods to insert, delete or swap individual atoms in molecular backbones could accelerate drug discovery.
item.dc:title: ‘Almost magical’: chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: India cuts periodic table and evolution from school textbooks — experts are baffled
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01770-y

Nature has learnt that the periodic table, as well as evolution, won’t be taught to under-16s as they start the new school year.
item.dc:title: India cuts periodic table and evolution from school textbooks — experts are baffled
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Satellite imagery identifies deliberate attacks on hospitals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01759-7

Satellite imagery identifies deliberate attacks on hospitals
item.dc:title: Satellite imagery identifies deliberate attacks on hospitals
item.dc:creator: Danielle N. Poole
Nathaniel A. Raymond
Kaveh Khoshnood

item.title: Electricity outages delay SDGs in sub-Saharan Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01757-9

Electricity outages delay SDGs in sub-Saharan Africa
item.dc:title: Electricity outages delay SDGs in sub-Saharan Africa
item.dc:creator: Qian Jia
Ying Wang
Zhenci Xu
Fengting Li

item.title: I use a robot to restore Pompeii’s shattered frescoes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01741-3

Cultural and heritage researcher Arianna Traviglia uses robotic technology to painstakingly reconstruct 2,000-year-old mural paintings in Pompeii.
item.dc:title: I use a robot to restore Pompeii’s shattered frescoes
item.dc:creator: Stav Dimitropoulos

item.title: Marine heatwaves: base definitions on ecosystem damage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01758-8

Marine heatwaves: base definitions on ecosystem damage
item.dc:title: Marine heatwaves: base definitions on ecosystem damage
item.dc:creator: Tiantian Li
Shilu Tong
Xiaoming Shi

item.title: From the archive: foods of the future and cryptography secrets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01742-2

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: foods of the future and cryptography secrets

item.title: A tool for optimizing messenger RNA sequence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01745-z

With messenger RNA therapeutics being developed for uses beyond vaccines, problems of RNA instability must be addressed. A new algorithm optimizes mRNA sequence for both stability and the encoding of amino acids.
item.dc:title: A tool for optimizing messenger RNA sequence
item.dc:creator: Anna K. Blakney

item.title: Why is India dropping evolution and the periodic table from school science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01750-2

India’s curriculum body needs to explain why it has removed foundational topics from school textbooks.
item.dc:title: Why is India dropping evolution and the periodic table from school science?

item.title: Why the world needs more transparency on the origins of novel pathogens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01722-6

Collaboration and openness are essential to minimize the risks of future pandemics, says the World Health Organization’s scientific advisory group, SAGO.
item.dc:title: Why the world needs more transparency on the origins of novel pathogens
item.dc:creator: Marietjie Venter

item.title: Why I’m leading Pacific Islands students in the fight on climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01751-1

Our voices were crucial in persuading UN states to back legal obligations to act on climate change. Here’s how we did it.
item.dc:title: Why I’m leading Pacific Islands students in the fight on climate change
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Houniuhi

item.title: Turkey’s researchers fear loss of freedom after Erdoğan re-elected
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01775-7

Researchers expect the administration to further restrict autonomy and free speech. Some say they will migrate or retire.
item.dc:title: Turkey’s researchers fear loss of freedom after Erdoğan re-elected
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Audio long read: Can giant surveys of scientists fight misinformation on COVID, climate change and more?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01706-6

Hoping to improve public debate and policymaking, multiple efforts have been launched to gather researchers' consensus views.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Can giant surveys of scientists fight misinformation on COVID, climate change and more?
item.dc:creator: David Adam
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Daily briefing: Why stress worsens inflammatory bowel disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01778-4

Brain cues produced by chronic stress lead to a cascade of events that eventually triggers immune cells in the gut. Plus, a key database that will guide deep-sea mining might be flawed and ‘tree islands’ can blunt the harm of oil-palm plantations.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why stress worsens inflammatory bowel disease
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: China is using satellites to police the protection of nature — but will it work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01714-6

Scientists say the system will help safeguard nature, but they want more transparency about the zones chosen for conservation.
item.dc:title: China is using satellites to police the protection of nature — but will it work?
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: To diversify the scientific workforce, postdoc recruitment needs a rethink
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01740-4

Biased hiring practices are limiting efforts to attract and retain researchers of colour.
item.dc:title: To diversify the scientific workforce, postdoc recruitment needs a rethink
item.dc:creator: Esther Landhuis

item.title: Ghosted in science: how to move on when a potential collaborator suddenly stops responding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01771-x

Don’t blame yourself if an enthusiastic and productive first encounter goes nowhere, says Aditya Simha.
item.dc:title: Ghosted in science: how to move on when a potential collaborator suddenly stops responding
item.dc:creator: Aditya Simha

item.title: Does brain stimulation boost memory and focus? Mega study tries to settle debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01727-1

Analysis of more than 100 studies of non-invasive electrical brain stimulation probes whether the controversial technology works.
item.dc:title: Does brain stimulation boost memory and focus? Mega study tries to settle debate
item.dc:creator: Emily Waltz

item.title: US will vaccinate birds against avian flu for first time — what researchers think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01760-0

The country plans to vaccinate endangered condors in an effort to curb unprecedented H5N1 outbreaks.
item.dc:title: US will vaccinate birds against avian flu for first time — what researchers think
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Saving the iconic Colorado River — scientists say latest plan is not enough
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01746-y

US states pledge to cut their use of water from the river, which has been drained by climate change and drought.
item.dc:title: Saving the iconic Colorado River — scientists say latest plan is not enough
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: SCUM of the Earth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01725-3

A question of balance.
item.dc:title: SCUM of the Earth
item.dc:creator: Richard A. Lovett

item.title: Anonymizing peer review makes the process more just
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01772-w

Authors from richer, English-speaking countries gain unconscious boost when identified to referees, study finds.
item.dc:title: Anonymizing peer review makes the process more just
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Trolled in science: “Hundreds of hateful comments in a single day”
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01399-x

Two researchers with direct experience of online abuse describe its impact, coping strategies, and how it compares to other types of harassment.
item.dc:title: Trolled in science: “Hundreds of hateful comments in a single day”

item.title: Author Correction: LACC1 bridges NOS2 and polyamine metabolism in inflammatory macrophages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06244-9

Author Correction: LACC1 bridges NOS2 and polyamine metabolism in inflammatory macrophages
item.dc:title: Author Correction: LACC1 bridges NOS2 and polyamine metabolism in inflammatory macrophages
item.dc:creator: Zheng Wei
Joonseok Oh
Richard A. Flavell
Jason M. Crawford

item.title: Better gummy sweets are within reach, thanks to physics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01696-5

Scientists have worked out the precise combination of ingredients needed to ensure that gummies keep their chew.
item.dc:title: Better gummy sweets are within reach, thanks to physics

item.title: Why scientists should be part of conversations about decolonizing humanities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01747-x

Sociologist Meghan Tinsley calls for a two-way dialogue about making university curricula more inclusive.
item.dc:title: Why scientists should be part of conversations about decolonizing humanities
item.dc:creator: Audrey Thompson

item.title: Daily briefing: Quantum computers are all ‘terrible’ — but researchers aren’t worried
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01761-z

Even the scientists who have made quantum computers their life’s work say they can’t do anything useful yet — but the future is bright. Plus, how China’s data privacy laws affects researchers and LIGO is back, better than ever.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Quantum computers are all ‘terrible’ — but researchers aren’t worried
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Chronic stress can inflame the gut — now scientists know why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01700-y

Signals originating in the brain make their way to gut nerve cells, leading to a release of inflammatory chemicals.
item.dc:title: Chronic stress can inflame the gut — now scientists know why
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: Decolonizing the humanities: striving to make the arts and media more diverse
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01734-2

For many students from under-represented backgrounds, the career pipeline into creative industries is blocked. Karen Patel leads an initiative to help fix it.
item.dc:title: Decolonizing the humanities: striving to make the arts and media more diverse
item.dc:creator: Audrey Thompson

item.title: China’s souped-up data privacy laws deter researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01638-1

Recent regulations have strengthened Chinese data privacy, but are impinging on international research collaboration.
item.dc:title: China’s souped-up data privacy laws deter researchers
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Major ocean database that will guide deep-sea mining has flaws, scientists warn
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01303-7

As sea-bed mining looms, researchers say better records of sea-floor biodiversity are needed to assess its environmental impact.
item.dc:title: Major ocean database that will guide deep-sea mining has flaws, scientists warn
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Equity is more than a buzzword
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01763-x

Departments and principal investigators must do the hard, uncomfortable work to cultivate truly inclusive, safe environments, says Ashley Paynter.
item.dc:title: Equity is more than a buzzword
item.dc:creator: Ashley Paynter

item.title: ‘Tree islands’ give oil-palm plantation a biodiversity boost
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01733-3

Five-year study shows islands increase ecosystem health without lowering crop yield, and a house built from concrete and nappies.
item.dc:title: ‘Tree islands’ give oil-palm plantation a biodiversity boost
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: The Spinoff Prize 2023
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01658-x

Nature introduces the finalists and those that made it on to the longlist for this year’s award.
item.dc:title: The Spinoff Prize 2023
item.dc:creator: Herb Brody

item.title: Towards quantum machine learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01718-2

Jungsang Kim discusses his interest in the pioneering technology.
item.dc:title: Towards quantum machine learning
item.dc:creator: Michael Brooks

item.title: Microbes take the ‘forever’ out of ‘forever chemicals’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01697-4

Bacteria that snip fluorine–carbon bonds can degrade certain kinds of PFAS, a class of environmental pollutant.
item.dc:title: Microbes take the ‘forever’ out of ‘forever chemicals’

item.title: Tree islands enhance biodiversity and functioning in oil palm landscapes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06086-5

A large-scale, five-year study in Indonesia finds that enriching oil palm-dominated landscapes with patches of trees bolsters biodiversity and ecosystem functioning without impairing oil palm yields but should not replace forest protection.
item.dc:title: Tree islands enhance biodiversity and functioning in oil palm landscapes
item.dc:creator: Delphine Clara Zemp

item.title: Ångström-resolution fluorescence microscopy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05925-9

The authors introduce a single-molecule DNA-barcoding method, resolution enhancement by sequential imaging, that improves the resolution of fluorescence microscopy down to the Ångström scale using off-the-shelf fluorescence microscopy hardware and reagents.
item.dc:title: Ångström-resolution fluorescence microscopy

item.title: Density-wave ordering in a unitary Fermi gas with photon-mediated interactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06018-3

An experiment with atoms and photons provides a fully tunable and microscopically controllable platform for the experimental study of the interplay of superfluidity and density-wave order.
item.dc:title: Density-wave ordering in a unitary Fermi gas with photon-mediated interactions
item.dc:creator: Victor Helson
Timo Zwettler
Farokh Mivehvar
Elvia Colella
Kevin Roux
Hideki Konishi
Helmut Ritsch
Jean-Philippe Brantut

item.title: A median fin derived from the lateral plate mesoderm and the origin of paired fins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06100-w

We identify that the larval zebrafish unpaired pre-anal fin fold is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, can be readily duplicated, and thus may represent a developmental intermediate between median and paired fins.
item.dc:title: A median fin derived from the lateral plate mesoderm and the origin of paired fins

item.title: Observing the onset of pressure-driven K-shell delocalization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05996-8

Experiments at the National Ignition Facility show how delocalization of K-shell electrons is driven by extreme pressure and temperature.
item.dc:title: Observing the onset of pressure-driven K-shell delocalization

item.title: Selective control of parasitic nematodes using bioactivated nematicides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06105-5

A metabolically bioactivated selective imidazothiazole nematicide shows comparable effectiveness at controlling plant root infection by Meloidogyne incognita to commercial nematicides, which are traditionally nonselective and toxic.
item.dc:title: Selective control of parasitic nematodes using bioactivated nematicides

item.title: Ubiquitination regulates ER-phagy and remodelling of endoplasmic reticulum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06089-2

Ubiquitination of the receptor FAM134B regulates ER-phagy and remodelling of the endoplasmic reticulum in response to cellular demands.
item.dc:title: Ubiquitination regulates ER-phagy and remodelling of endoplasmic reticulum
item.dc:creator: Alexis González

item.title: Histone modifications regulate pioneer transcription factor cooperativity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06112-6

Binding of the human pioneer transcription factor OCT4 to nucleosomes containing endogenous DNA sequences causes changes to the nucleosome structure and facilitates the cooperative assembly of multiple pioneer transcription factors, a property that can be affected by histone modifications.
item.dc:title: Histone modifications regulate pioneer transcription factor cooperativity
item.dc:creator: Kalyan K. Sinha
Silvija Bilokapic
Yongming Du
Deepshikha Malik
Mario Halic

item.title: Programming inactive RNA-binding small molecules into bioactive degraders
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06091-8

Small-molecule RNA-targeted degradation can be leveraged to convert strong, yet inactive, binding interactions into potent and specific modulators of RNA function.
item.dc:title: Programming inactive RNA-binding small molecules into bioactive degraders
item.dc:creator: Yuquan Tong
Yeongju Lee

item.title: Gap junctions desynchronize a neural circuit to stabilize insect flight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06099-0

In the Drosophila central-pattern-generating neural network, a mechanism for network desynchronization relying on weak electrical synapses and specific excitability dynamics of the coupled neurons translates unpatterned premotor input into stereotyped neuronal firing with fixed sequences of cell activation, ensuring stable wingbeat power.
item.dc:title: Gap junctions desynchronize a neural circuit to stabilize insect flight
item.dc:creator: Silvan Hürkey
Nelson Niemeyer
Jan-Hendrik Schleimer
Stefanie Ryglewski
Susanne Schreiber
Carsten Duch

item.title: γ-Linolenic acid in maternal milk drives cardiac metabolic maturation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06068-7

The switch from glucose- to fatty acid-dependent metabolism in cardiomyocytes of newborn mice is governed by γ-linolenic acid in maternal milk, which binds to retinoid X receptors, thereby causing a transcription-dependent metabolic transition.
item.dc:title: γ-Linolenic acid in maternal milk drives cardiac metabolic maturation
item.dc:creator: Ana Paredes

item.title: Lead immobilization for environmentally sustainable perovskite solar cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05938-4

An analysis of chemical processes to immobilize lead from perovskite solar cells is presented, highlighting the need for a standard lead-leakage test and mathematical model to reliably evaluate the potential environmental risk of perovskite optoelectronics.
item.dc:title: Lead immobilization for environmentally sustainable perovskite solar cells
item.dc:creator: Hui Zhang
Jin-Wook Lee

Nam-Gyu Park

item.title: Microbial carbon use efficiency promotes global soil carbon storage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06042-3

A deep learning and data-driven modelling study finds that microbial carbon use efficiency is a major determinant of soil organic carbon storage and its spatial variation across the globe.
item.dc:title: Microbial carbon use efficiency promotes global soil carbon storage

item.title: Dynamics, interactions and delays of the 2019 Ridgecrest rupture sequence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05985-x

Data-assimilated three-dimensional dynamic rupture models of the 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake sequence in California are used to reveal the dynamics, interactions and delays of the earthquake sequence.
item.dc:title: Dynamics, interactions and delays of the 2019 Ridgecrest rupture sequence
item.dc:creator: Taufiq Taufiqurrahman

František Gallovič

item.title: Flexible solar cells based on foldable silicon wafers with blunted edges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05921-z

Modules of foldable crystalline silicon solar cells retain their power-conversion efficiency after being subjected to bending stress or exposure to air-flow simulations of a violent storm.
item.dc:title: Flexible solar cells based on foldable silicon wafers with blunted edges

item.title: Walking naturally after spinal cord injury using a brain–spine interface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06094-5

A reliable digital bridge restored communication between the brain and spinal cord and enabled natural walking in a participant with spinal cord injury.
item.dc:title: Walking naturally after spinal cord injury using a brain–spine interface

item.title: Structural basis of amine odorant perception by a mammal olfactory receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06106-4

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of mouse trace amine-associated receptor 9 reveals structural motifs involved in odorant ligand recognition, including a unique disulfide bond linking the N terminus to extracellular loop 2.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of amine odorant perception by a mammal olfactory receptor
item.dc:creator: Lulu Guo

item.title: Users choose to engage with more partisan news than they are exposed to on Google Search
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06078-5

Ecologically valid data collected during the 2018 and 2020 US elections show that exposure to and engagement with partisan or unreliable news on Google Search are driven not primarily by algorithmic curation but by users’ own choices.
item.dc:title: Users choose to engage with more partisan news than they are exposed to on Google Search
item.dc:creator: Ronald E. Robertson
Jon Green
Damian J. Ruck
Katherine Ognyanova
Christo Wilson
David Lazer

item.title: Mitotic bookmarking by SWI/SNF subunits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06085-6

Subunits of SWI/SNF act as mitotic bookmarks to safeguard cell identity during cell division.
item.dc:title: Mitotic bookmarking by SWI/SNF subunits
item.dc:creator: Zhexin Zhu
Xiaolong Chen
Ao Guo

item.title: Orbital Fulde–Ferrell–Larkin–Ovchinnikov state in an Ising superconductor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05967-z

The discovery of an orbital Fulde–Ferrell–Larkin–Ovchinnikov state in the multilayer Ising superconductor 2H-NbSe2, in which the translational and rotational symmetries are broken, enables the preparation of such states in other materials with broken inversion symmetries.
item.dc:title: Orbital Fulde–Ferrell–Larkin–Ovchinnikov state in an Ising superconductor

Jianting Ye

item.title: Dynamic optical response of solids following 1-fs-scale photoinjection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05986-w

Petahertz-scale optical-field metrology in a pump-probe setting enables the direct observation of how the optical properties of a medium evolve after 1-fs-scale photoinjection.
item.dc:title: Dynamic optical response of solids following 1-fs-scale photoinjection
item.dc:creator: Dmitry A. Zimin
Nicholas Karpowicz
Muhammad Qasim
Matthew Weidman
Ferenc Krausz
Vladislav S. Yakovlev

item.title: A Pseudomonas aeruginosa small RNA regulates chronic and acute infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06111-7

A study examining bacterial gene expression in human-derived samples identifies a gene encoding a small RNA and describes how it orchestrates the transition between chronic and acute infection in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
item.dc:title: A Pseudomonas aeruginosa small RNA regulates chronic and acute infection
item.dc:creator: Pengbo Cao

item.title: Observation of the radiative decay of the <sup>229</sup>Th nuclear clock isomer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05894-z

The authors report on the radiative decay of a low-energy isomer in thorium-229 (229mTh), which has consequences for the design of a future nuclear clock and eases the search for direct laser excitation of the atomic nucleus.
item.dc:title: Observation of the radiative decay of the <sup>229</sup>Th nuclear clock isomer

item.title: A small-molecule PI3Kα activator for cardioprotection and neuroregeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05972-2

A new specific, small-molecule activator of the PI3Kα isoform (UCL-TRO-1938) identified through high-throughput screening can transiently activate PI3K signalling and biological responses in cells and tissues, with potential therapeutic applications in tissue protection and regeneration.
item.dc:title: A small-molecule PI3Kα activator for cardioprotection and neuroregeneration

item.title: Heteromeric clusters of ubiquitinated ER-shaping proteins drive ER-phagy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06090-9

The membrane-shaping protein ARL6IP1 is involved in the selective degradation of the endoplasmic reticulum, and this process depends on its ubiquitination and interaction with other membrane-shaping proteins such as FAM134B.
item.dc:title: Heteromeric clusters of ubiquitinated ER-shaping proteins drive ER-phagy
item.dc:creator: Hector Foronda
Yangxue Fu
Adriana Covarrubias-Pinto

item.title: Tumour extracellular vesicles and particles induce liver metabolic dysfunction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06114-4

Remote tumours cause liver dysfunction by releasing extracellular vesicles and particles containing palmitic acid, which induces TNF signalling in Kupffer cells, resulting in inflammation, fatty deposits and metabolic dysregulation, thus both reducing the efficacy and increasing the toxicity of chemotherapies.
item.dc:title: Tumour extracellular vesicles and particles induce liver metabolic dysfunction

item.title: A fat-blocking drug could help to fight metastatic cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01648-z

The antibody drug is moving closer to being tested in people with advanced stages of cancer.
item.dc:title: A fat-blocking drug could help to fight metastatic cancer
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Photon lights a path towards a nuclear clock
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01631-8

A long-sought photon that is emitted by the nucleus of a thorium isotope has now been observed. The feat is a key step in efforts to build a nuclear clock, a device that is precise enough to probe the Universe’s best-kept secrets.
item.dc:title: Photon lights a path towards a nuclear clock
item.dc:creator: Adriana Pálffy

item.title: Listening for neurological symptoms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01650-5

Unusual vocal patterns can give clues that help to detect conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease.
item.dc:title: Listening for neurological symptoms
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: Daily briefing: Why orcas are attacking boats in Spain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01754-y

Endangered orcas that have sunk three boats might have learnt from one traumatized individual. Plus, what scientists are learning as game-changing obesity drugs go mainstream and what to do about the mental-health crisis gripping science.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why orcas are attacking boats in Spain
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Accelerating drug development with 3D neural models
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01646-1

A reproducible cell-culture system could help to evaluate new therapies for disorders that affect the brain.
item.dc:title: Accelerating drug development with 3D neural models
item.dc:creator: Christine Evans-Pughe
